title: How to Make a Water Purifier

steps.headline: Get a clean pot and clean storage containers.
steps.description: To disinfect your water, you'll need a clean pot as well as clean containers to store the water in after you've disinfected it. Your storage containers should have lids that will close tightly, to ensure the water doesn't become contaminated again. If you're reusing bottles, use soft drink bottles rather than bottles that previously held milk or fruit juice. Milk and juice sugars contribute to bacterial growth in stored water. Clean bottles thoroughly using a dish soap. You can also sanitize bottles with 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of household chlorine bleach for every quart (liter) of water.

steps.headline: Strain your water.
steps.description: While disinfection kills most microorganisms that could cause health problems, it doesn't get rid of heavy metals, salts, and other chemicals. Before you disinfect your water, pour it through a cloth or coffee filter to help eliminate these contaminants. You can also let your water sit in bottles for several hours before disinfecting it. The heavier particles will settle to the bottom, and you can pour the water from the top of the bottle, leaving the sediment behind.

steps.headline: Boil your water.
steps.description: Fill a large pot or kettle with water and bring it to a rolling boil. Allow the water to boil for at least a minute and as long as 5 minutes. Some of your water will evaporate. Let the water cool before trying to drink it or pouring it into plastic bottles. Boiling water is the safest and most effective way to clean it so that it will be drinkable. Boiled water tastes better if you add oxygen to it by pouring it back and forth several times between two clean containers. If you're out in the wilderness or don't have electricity, you can still boil water over a fire, or by gradually adding externally heated rocks to the water until it begins to boil.

steps.headline: Chlorinate your water.
steps.description: Household liquid bleach also kills microorganisms in water. Use only regular household bleach that contains between 5.25 and 6 percent sodium hypochlorite. Your bleach should be unscented, contain no other cleaners or chemicals, and come from a new or recently opened bottle. Add 16 drops of bleach to 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water. Stir and let it stand for 30 minutes. The water should have a slight bleach odor. If it doesn't, repeat the method and let it stand for another 15 minutes. Water disinfected with bleach that does not have a slight bleach odor is not safe to drink. Find another source of water, or use another method of disinfection.

steps.headline: Use the solar water disinfection (SODIS) method.
steps.description: If you can't boil water and don't have any bleach, you can harness the energy of the sun to disinfect your water. All you need are some soft drink bottles with caps. Fill your bottles with water and close the caps tightly. Set the bottles out in an area where they will receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight. After 6 hours, the water is safe to drink. This method only works with PET bottles. Glass blocks crucial UV rays that are needed to properly disinfect the water. For best results, place your bottles on a conductive material, such as a tin roof, and angle them towards the sun.

steps.headline: Pour water through a cloth or coffee filter.
steps.description: If your water is cloudy, simply pouring it through a a piece of cloth or a coffee filter will remove most of the sediment. This method also removes dirt and debris from water found in a natural source, such as a stream or river. Filtering water through cloth is only the first step in the filtration process. While it can make the water less cloudy, it won't effectively clean your water or make it safe for drinking.

steps.headline: Buy filtering materials in advance.
steps.description: You can make a simple bio-filter that mimics the filtration process of the earth, but you have to plan ahead. You'll need empty soft drink bottles, gravel, sand, and activated filter carbon or charcoal. Gravel and sand can be purchased at hardware and home improvement stores, as well as some discount stores. To buy activated filter carbon or activated charcoal, head to a pet store and look for it in the aquarium supplies.

steps.headline: Build a bio-filter.
steps.description: Cut your soft drink bottles in half, and nestle the top half upside down inside the bottom half. Place a napkin or paper towel into the neck of the top bottle, then add your filter materials. Place sand at the bottom of the filter on top of the paper towel, followed by a layer of charcoal. Top your filter off with a layer of gravel. Gravel and sand remove contaminants in the water, while the charcoal removes pesticides and chemicals as well as improving the flavor.

steps.headline: Pour water through your filter.
steps.description: Once you've set up your filter, pour your water slowly through the top. The water will filter through your layers into the bottom-half of the bottle. You may have to run water through the filter several times to get drinkable water. The charcoal may give the water a slightly gray color. As long as the water is otherwise clear, this won't harm you.

steps.headline: Disinfect water after filtering it.
steps.description: Filtering water does not kill all viruses and bacteria that may be  present. To be absolutely certain that your water is clean and safe, boil or chlorinate your water after filtering it. Water disinfectant tablets with chlorine dioxide can also be effective to disinfect filtered water, provided you follow the manufacturer's instructions for use.

steps.headline: Gather supplies to make a simple distillation system.
steps.description: Commercial home distillation systems can be pretty expensive, but you can make one that achieves similar results using a large stock pot with a lid, a cup, and some twine. Your string should be thick enough and strong enough that it will not break when exposed to moisture. You can also use fishing line or other plastic twine. If you plan to distill water in case of an emergency or natural disaster, it's a good idea to get these materials together before disaster strikes and keep them with other emergency supplies. You might also want to practice the method to make sure you know how to do it.

steps.headline: Tie a cup to the handle of the pot's lid.
steps.description: Using your twine, tie the cup to the pot's lid so that when the lid is upside down, the cup is suspended below it. Make sure the cup is hanging right-side up so that it will fill with water. Experiment with wrapping the twine around the cup to cradle it so that it stays upright. If it's tilting, it won't get as much water.

steps.headline: Check the depth of the cup.
steps.description: Once you've secured your cup to the lid, place the lid on your stock pot upside down and see how far the cup hangs below the lid. This will give you an idea of how much water you can put in your stock pot. Since you likely can't see through the sides of your stock pot, hold the lid to the side of the pot at the level where it would sit if it were on the pot. Then make a mark where the bottom of the cup falls on the pot.

steps.headline: Fill your pot no more than half-full with water.
steps.description: The amount of water you can distill at one time will depend on how big your pot is. Generally, you won't be able to fill the pot more than half full and still have room for the cup. The water level should not be high enough to reach the bottom of the cup.

steps.headline: Boil the water for at least 20 minutes.
steps.description: Bring the water to a rolling boil, then immediately place the lid on the pot upside down, so that the cup hangs in the pot under the lid. The water in the pot will vaporize as the water boils. The vapor will condense and drink into the cup. As the water vaporizes, all microorganisms are killed. Heavy metals, salts, and other chemicals are also removed.

steps.headline: Drink the water from the cup.
steps.description: The vapor that condenses and drips into the cup is clean of all contaminants and safe to drink. Depending on the size of your stock pot, however, you may have to repeat the process several times before you have enough water to drink. Unlike filtration or disinfection, distilled water does not require any additional treatment before you drink it.

text: Disinfecting Water Get a clean pot and clean storage containers. To disinfect your water, you'll need a clean pot as well as clean containers to store the water in after you've disinfected it. While it can make the water less cloudy, it won't effectively clean your water or make it safe for drinking. Buy filtering materials in advance. You'll need empty soft drink bottles, gravel, sand, and activated filter carbon or charcoal. Gravel and sand can be purchased at hardware and home improvement stores, as well as some discount stores. Then make a mark where the bottom of the cup falls on the pot. Fill your pot no more than half-full with water. The amount of water you can distill at one time will depend on how big your pot is.
